column1: "I think it's a pyramid scheme. I'm just surprised it isn't even lower," he said on "Squawk on the Street" Bitcoin tumbled to a six-week low early Tuesday, falling below $12,000 for the first time since Dec. 5.Comments from South Korea's finance minister renewed concerns about a crackdown in one of the largest markets for digital currency trading.
column2: The iShares Nasdaq Biotech ETF is up 2.3 percent Monday, following its 5 percent decline this month through Friday. Novartis said on Monday it plans to buy the gene therapy company in a cash deal totaling $8.7 billion or $218 per share. Verastem stock is up about 9 percent after it announced its New Drug Application filing with priority review for its duvelisib, a treatment for lymphoma.
column3: The White House is likely to introduce new tariffs designed to combat China's alleged unfair trade practices, a report says. The U.S. leader has frequently identified apparent trade imbalances as a problem he wants to resolve. Trump is set to refocus on one of a handful of major policy areas on which the president can act without having to rely on Congress. A spokesperson for the White House was not immediately available for comment.
column4: The deal between the U.S. startup and Saudi Arabia's top sovereign wealth fund is expected to be announced in the coming weeks. The Florida-based startup raised $502 million in October in a capital funding round led by Singapore government-owned investment firm Temasek Holdings. Magic Leap and the Public Investment Fund did not respond to requests for comment outside regular business hours. (Reporting by Kanishka Singh in Bengaluru; Editing by Tom Brown)
column5: The Lego Group announced pieces such as leaves, bushes and trees will be made of a plant-based plastic using sugarcane. The shift is part of a bigger plan to use sustainable products in its products and packaging by 2030. The move is among several Lego has taken to create a manufacturing process friendlier to the environment. Last year, Lego announced it was partnering with World Wildlife Fund (WWF) to reduce carbon dioxide emissions.
column6: Hawaii Volcanoes National Park has been shut down since the Kilauea volcano began spewing lava and toxic gases earlier this month. Both Norwegian Cruise Lines and Royal Caribbean have cancelled stops at Hilo, the Big Island's port. Tourism authorities said summer bookings for hotels on the island have fallen almost 50 percent since the eruption started on May 3. The closure of the national park is costing the island $166 million, the National Park Service said on Monday.
column7: The dividend is payable on to holders of record at the close of business on . The dividend is an "eligible" dividend for purposes of the Income Tax Act (Canada) and any similar provincial/territorial legislation. Canadian Pacific is a transcontinental railway in Canada and the United States with direct links to major ports on the west and east coasts. Visit cpr.ca to see the rail advantages of CP.
column8: Shares of the popular social media company were up 5 percent early Wednesday. They had plunged 10 percent on Tuesday following reports that the company could face new regulation abroad. The social media space has been under pressure this week amid growing investor skepticism over Facebook' s data-sharing scandal. On Tuesday, one trader bought a block of 2,000 May 32 calls for $2.77. This is a bullish bet that Twitter shares will be above $34.77 by May.
column9: Bitcoin surged Thursday, briefly above $8,000 per coin on the Coinbase exchange. Bitcoin has been bottoming out over the last week, $500 higher than its lows in February of $6,000. I am looking to positive developments from various cryptocurrency exchanges in the coming months, which should be supportive to the market. I believe the cryptocurrency space is most bullish when these two are working together.
column10: "Futures Now" traders share their trades as geopolitical concerns rocked stocks, bonds and crude market. Scott Nations is buying the August monthly 70-strike calls in the crude oil futures July contract for $1.05, or $105 per options contract. Brian Stutland is long the S&P e-mini using options. He is also long the VIX, and has no position in crude or the 10-year Treasury futures.
column11: GoPro is offering a free new camera if they ever break their current one. The service also includes unlimited photo storage and 35 hours of cloud video storage. GoPro said cloud backup will be available for iPhone users on February 20 and for Android later this spring. The company issued weak guidance and announced plans to eliminate 20 percent of its workforce earlier this month. GoPro said it plans to roll out the option globally later this year.
column12: Tesla is being probed by a California agency for occupational safety after a report that the electric carmaker failed to disclose serious injuries at a Fremont factory. The state's Occupational Safety and Health Administration (Cal-OSHA) disclosed the inspection on Wednesday. Tesla spokesman: "We have never in the entire history of our company received a violation for inaccurate or incomplete injury record-keeping"
column13: United Technologies is looking into breaking up its portfolio of businesses. CEO Greg Hayes said a decision on the matter will be made by year-end. The move may be following General Electric 's lead, another member of the Dow. shares of United Technologies are up 18.7 percent over the past year, lagging the Dow which has risen 20.2 percent in that time.. GE, meanwhile, has shed more than half of its value over thepast year.
column14: Global property reinsurance prices rise less than expected in key Jan. 1 renewal season. Strong competition limiting increases to single digit percentages, brokers say. Reinsurance sector has turned the corner after five years of falling prices, JLT Re says. Last year was a record year of $140 billion in insurance losses, broker JLT says.. Catastrophe bond managers are launching new funds and hedge funds have bought reinsurance stocks.
column15: SandRidge Energy, Inc. will release its 2017 fourth quarter and full year financial and operational results after the close of trading on the New York Stock Exchange on Wednesday, . The company will host a conference call to discuss these results on Thursday, at 8:00am CT. The telephone number to access the conference call from within the U.S. is (833) 245-9650. The passcode for the call is 44899
column16: West and Trump have exchanged pleasantries in the past. This is their first exchange on Twitter since Trump's inauguration. West posted a series of photos of himself wearing the "Make America Great Again" baseball cap made famous during the 2016 campaign. He told his audience during a performance after the election that "If I would've voted, I would have voted [for] Trump" He also met with Trump at Trump Tower in December 2016.
column17: Brazilian agency requires Apple to inform consumers on batteries. Apple apologized on Dec. 28 over its handling of the battery issue. The company said it would cut the price of an out-of-warranty battery replacement from $79 to $29 for an iPhone 6 or later, starting this month. The agency has the power to fine or propose legal action against companies for causing losses to consumers.
column18: Purcell Julie & Lefkowitz LLP is investigating a potential breach of fiduciary duty claim involving the board of directors of Pinnacle Financial Partners, Inc. (NASDAQ: PNFP) If you are a shareholder and are interested in obtaining additional information regarding this investigation, please visit us at: may also contact Robert H. LefKowitz, Esq. either
column19: Bond prices, which move inversely to yields, are now looking oversold, said Larry McDonald, editor of the Bear Traps Report. The U.S. 10-year yield is much higher than in Japan and Germany, but a global shortage of dollars has increased the cost of hedging these bonds. The spot between a 3.1 percent and 3.15 percent yield offers a good buying opportunity on the TBT ProShares UltraShort Treasury ETF.
column20: Old Point Financial Corporation has declared a quarterly cash dividend of $0.11 per share on its common capital stock to be paid on . Based on the stock's closing price of $26.34 on , the dividend yield is approximately 1.7%. The dividend is consistent with the prior quarter's dividend and is paid to shareholders of record as of May 31.
column21: Democratic Republic of Congo has 39 suspected, probable and confirmed cases of Ebola since April. U.S. Food and Drug Administration Commissioner Scott Gottlieb says health officials are "in a very different posture" than last time. An outbreak in West Africa in 2014 was the deadliest occurrence of the disease since it was discovered in 1976, killing more than 11,300 people, according to the WHO.
column22: Several people identifying themselves on social media as employees at the Google -owned video company or as being on present at the scene have reported hearing shots. Todd Sherman, who lists himself as a product manager at YouTube on his Twitter profile, wrote a series of tweets saying that he heard running while in a meeting. Police have reported to YouTube's headquarters on reports of an active shooter, San Bruno police confirm.
column23: Nektar Therapeutics will announce its financial results for the fourth quarter and year-ended , on Thursday, . Howard Robin, president and chief executive officer, will host a conference call to review the results. The press release and a live audio-only Webcast of the conference call can be accessed through a link that is posted on the home page and Investors section of the Nektar website:
column24: White House reportedly to threaten China with tech investment ban. U.S. may release details as early as next week on which Chinese products could be targeted in the administration's preliminary call for 25 percent tariffs on $100 billion worth of imports. The report said the ban on Chinese investment in U.s. technology could be permanent. Last month, the U. S. slapped tariffs on up to $60 billion in annual Chinese imports.
column25: Mark Zuckerberg is testifying before the House Energy and Commerce Committee Wednesday. He appeared at a joint hearing of the Senate Judiciary and Commerce committees Tuesday. Zuckerberg is likely to face more tough questions on user privacy, foreign meddling on the site and abuse of social media tools. He is facing questions following reports that Cambridge Analytica improperly gained access to the personal data of as many as 87 million Facebook users.
column26: Randal Quarles is a member of the Federal Reserve's Board of Governors. He is expected to take a lighter hand at regulation following the post-financial crisis reforms. Investors widely expect the policymaking Federal Open Market Committee to approve three interest rate hikes this year.Quarles' speech comes a day ahead of congressional testimony from new Fed Chairman Jerome Powell. The speech is slated to start at 3:15 pm, ET.
column27: AT&T has backed off from a deal to sell smartphones made by Chinese Huawei Technologies Co Ltd, the Wall Street Journal reported. Huawei spokesman Charles Zinkowski said the company would announce new products for the U.S. market on Tuesday. Huawei phones are available for purchase in the United States but have never been distributed by a major carrier. Neither company has ever confirmed that they were in talks.
column28: Silgan is a leading supplier of rigid packaging for consumer goods products with annual net sales of approximately $4.1 billion in 2017. The Board of Directors approved a $0.10 per share quarterly cash dividend, payable on to the holders of record of common stock of the Company on . Silgan operates 99 manufacturing facilities in North and South America, Europe and Asia.
column29: Payments processing company Square sold $34.1 million in bitcoin in the first quarter. However, the company spent $33.9 million to buy bitcoin to allow people to trade it through its Cash mobile payments app. As a result, adjusted revenue from bitcoin was just $200,000.Square, headed by Twitter co-founder Jack Dorsey , launched trading in the cryptocurrency through the Cash app in January.
column30: Shares of Alcoa fell more than 5 percent in extended trading. Plexus stock plunged nearly 6.8 percent after the electronic components and systems manufacturer reported first quarter financial results. Apple announced it would award eligible employees $2,500 in stock-based compensation. The news followed a rash of announcements from Apple that emphasized its commitment to the U.S. economy through foreign capital repatriation efforts and long-term economic contribution.
column31: Trump and May spoke after May's senior ministers gave her their backing to take action with the U.S. and France to tackle the use of chemical weapons by the government of Syria. "They agreed to keep working closely together on the international response," the British prime minister's office said in a statement. The two leaders agreed it was "vital" that chemical weapons did not go unchallenged, the statement added.
column32: Net profit for the first three months of 2018 for the company known formally as Hon Hai Precision Industry reached $24.08 billion ($809 million) That was down 14.5 percent from $28.168 billion a year earlier, according to Reuters' calculations. In May, Apple reported resilient iPhone sales in the face of waning global demand. Foxconn assembles electronic devices including iPhones for Apple, which is a major customer.

The Company will conduct its quarterly conference call on Thursday, , at 9:00 AM ET. column35: Cornerstone OnDemand Inc. (CSOD) on Tuesday reported a loss of $16.2 million in its first quarter. The results surpassed Wall Street expectations. The developer of human-resources software posted revenue of $133.1 million in the period. For the current quarter ending in July, Cornerstone Ondemand said it expects revenue in the range of $127 million to $129 million.

Management will host a conference call and webcast to discuss the Company's financial results at 4:30 p.m. ET that same day. column37: The Dow Jones industrial average saw its sixth straight day of gains Thursday. Jim Paulsen isn't convinced the concerns that dragged the market down recently have gone away. The central issue is the pressure from an overheating economy and the need for rates to be reset higher, he said. "Job creation is still too strong for a fully employed economy not to have wages and inflation go up further," said Paulsen.
column38: Tim Draper: "There's a real need for a currency that's global" Draper has made a personal fortune on bitcoin. He said in May that he was participating in the Tezos ICO, one of the biggest crypto offerings of the past year. The event was so crowded that people were filling up the overflow room to listen on televisions, and Draper's video aired late because of technical difficulties.
column39: Jerome Powell said he doesn't see any significant risks in the current financial system. He cited how the banking sector has higher liquidity, less leverage, and lower risk taking compared to the financial crisis. The Federal Reserve said the price-earnings ratios for U.S. stocks were "close to their highest levels outside of the 1990s" in its "Monetary Policy Report" released last month.
column40: Delta says only "a small subset" of customers were affected. The airline says the incident involved a chat-services provider used by Delta and other companies. Delta says it will make sure customers aren't held responsible if their payment cards were used fraudulently. (24)7.ai says a "small number" of its client companies had their online customer payment information potentially exposed, but it is confident its platform is now secure.
column41: The Walt Disney Co. (DIS) on Tuesday reported fiscal second-quarter profit of $2.94 billion. The results surpassed Wall Street expectations. The entertainment company posted revenue of $14.55 billion in the period.Disney shares have declined 5 percent since the beginning of the year, while the Standard & Poor's 500 index has stayed nearly flat.. In the final minutes of trading on Tuesday, shares hit $101.90, a decrease of 8.5 percent in the
column42: Cytokinetics Inc. (CYTK) on Thursday reported a fourth-quarter loss of $40.5 million. The South San Francisco, California-based company said it had a loss of 75 cents. The results did not meet Wall Street expectations. In the final minutes of trading on Thursday, shares hit $8.55, a drop of 25 percent in the last 12 months.
column43: Michael Cohen says FBI agents were respectful and professional when they raided his home and office on Monday. The attorney said "[he] would be lying" if he said he wasn't worried about the search, which is reportedly related to payments made to two women who claim to have had affairs with Trump. Federal prosecutors in New York obtained a search warrant to carry out the raid. It followed a referral from special counsel Robert Mueller, who is investigating Russian efforts to interfere in the 2016 election.
column44: Infinity Pharmaceuticals, Inc. will host a conference call on Thursday, , at 4:30 p.m. ET to review its fourth quarter and full year 2017 financial results and provide an update on the company. A live webcast of the conference call can be accessed in the Investors/Media section of Infinity's website at . To participate in the call, please dial 1-877-316-5293 (domestic)
column45: A janitor in South Korea who discovered seven gold bars in a garbage bin could keep them if no-one else claims ownership. The owner of the bullion is a Korean man, according to Seoul-based Yonhap News Agency. Two other men ditched the bars at the request of the owner out of fear of being searched at customs. Police said that the men were traveling from Hong Kong to Japan, and went through South Korea in the belief that it would be easier to bypass
column46: The set-top box maker's shares were up 13 percent at $15.30 in after-hours trading. TiVo's stock price is at a level that the company and its board do not believe reflects the true value of the business, the company said. The company is also considering options including acquisitions and merging with leading players, it said.TiVo's profit came in at $18.4 million in the quarter ended Dec. 31.
column47: The stock index is also tracking for a weekly loss of about 6 percent, its worst since October 2008, during the financial crisis. In the past five trading days, including Friday, the Dow has traded about 20,000 points back and forth in a roughly 2,000-point trading range. The CBOE Volatility Index (.VIX) jumped Tuesday above 50 for the first time since the market turmoil of August 2015.
column48: UBS reiterates its buy rating on Apple shares. The recently passed tax reform law will free up new funds for the company's shareholder return program. UBS estimates repatriation will unleash an incremental $25 billion. As a result, Milunovich believes the company could buy back $122 billion worth of its shares through 2019. The analyst has a $190 price target for Apple shares, representing 9 percent upside to Friday's close.
column49: U.S. must reckon with Europe responding in kind if it declares "America First" and places its own economic interests before those of others, says Germany's Economy Minister. Peter Altmaier attributed the U.S.'s desire to block the building of a new pipeline linking Russia and Germany under the Baltic Sea to its need to secure markets for its own liquid natural gas (LNG) exports.
column50: Dropbox Inc's initial public offering was priced at $21 per share, CNBC reported. The cloud-based file-storage firm raised its expected price range by $2 to $18 to $20 per share. Dropbox shares are set to start trading on Friday at the Nasdaq under the symbol "DBX" The IPO raised about $756 million in the largest tech IPO since Snap Inc raised $3.9 billion in its debut last year.
column51: Toscana Energy Income Corporation provides an update to its Normal Course Issuer Bid. Canaccord Genuity Corp. will be replacing National Bank Financial Inc. as the broker firm responsible for making purchases of common shares in the capital of Toscana. Purchases under the Bid are permitted to commence at the opening of the markets on . The Bid will terminate on the earlier of: (a) the date on which the maximum number of Common Shares are purchased pursuant
column52: The Atlanta-based home improvement retailer joins a growing list of corporations, including Starbucks and Disney , using new tax benefits to give workers bonuses and raise pay. Home Depot's bonus amounts will be determined based on a person's length of service, similar to Walmart's strategy. The retailer also said the new tax law will result in added tax expenses of about $150 million (related to offshore earnings) in the fourth quarter.
column53: Optibase invests in the fixed-income real estate field and currently holds properties and beneficial interest in real-estate assets and projects in Switzerland, Germany and in Texas, Philadelphia, PA and Miami, FL, Chicago, IL, USA. Shareholders may receive a hard copy of the annual report free of charge upon request. This press release is being issued pursuant to NASDAQ Listing Rule 5250(d)(1)(C)
column54: The Board of Directors of Apogee Enterprises, Inc. has declared a quarterly cash dividend of $0.1575 per share. The dividend is payable on to shareholders of record on . The company is organized in four segments, with three of the segments serving the commercial construction market: Architectural Framing Systems, Architectural Glass and Architectural Services.
column55: Mark Begor will take over from Paulino do Rego Barros Jr., who became interim CEO in September when Richard Smith stepped down. Begor most recently served as a managing director at Warburg Pincus. Prior to that, he spent 35 years at General Electric in a variety of positions, including as president and CEO of GE Energy Management. About 147.9 million Americans have been impacted by Equifax's data breach.

(Eastern) Senior management will hold a conference call on that day at 11:00 A.m. column57: Haemonetics Corporation (NYSE: HAE) announced that third quarter and year-to-date fiscal 2018 financial results are available on its Investor relations website. The Company will host a conference call with investors and analysts to discuss and answer questions about the results at 8:00am Eastern Time on . A live webcast of the call can be accessed on Haemonetics' Investor Relations website.
column58: Erie Insurance has appointed Kim Kaercher as Corporate Marketing Officer with oversight of ERIE's marketing strategy and functions. Before coming to EriE, she served as marketing manager at two national companies. Erie Insurance Group is the 10 th largest homeowners insurer and 11 th largest automobile insurer in the United States. The Group, rated A+ by A.M. Best Company, has more than 5 million policies in force and operates in 12 states and the District of Columbia.
column59: Netflix is set to report earnings after the bell on Monday. The company remains the dominant over-the-top video provider by many metrics. But Monday's earnings report comes amid challenges for the company. Netflix said in October that its $10 per month high-definition plan would rise to $11. It's been nearly 6 months since Disney said it planned to pull its movies from Netflix in favor of its own service.
column60: Instagram will soon allow its users to download a copy of all the content they have uploaded on the photo-sharing platform. The disclosure comes amid global concerns about the privacy of users' information on social media platforms. If the tool is launched before May 25, it will help Instagram comply with upcoming European privacy laws that require data portability, TechCrunch said. Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg answered questions from U.S. lawmakers about data privacy on Wednesday.
column61: ABcann Global Corporation (TSXV:ABCN) (Frankfurt:23Q) (OTC:ABCCF) announced that Ken Clement, ABcann's founder and director, has resigned from the Board of Directors. The Company holds production and sales licenses from Health Canada. Its flagship facility in Napanee, Ontario contains proprietary plant-growing technology, centred on its specially designed, environmentally-controlled growing chambers.
column62: The move is seen as part of Tehran's efforts to control the currency market after the rial hit an all-time low earlier this month. Though cryptocurrencies, such as bitcoin, have never been authorized in Iran, they were available in parallel markets. Transactions are typically anonymous but the currency can be converted into cash when deposited into accounts at prices set in online trading. The ban applies to "all monetary and financial centers of the country," including banks and currency exchange offices.
column63: Corona maker Constellation Brands quarterly results top estimates. The maker of Robert Mondavi wines and Svedka vodka said sales rose 8.5 percent to $1.77 billion. The company also raised quarterly dividends by 42 percent each on its Class A and Class B shares.Shares of the company rose nearly 3 percent in premarket trading on Thursday. The latest quarter was helped by a $363 million gain due to the recently enacted U.S. tax law.
column64: Wynn filed a lawsuit against Jorgen Nielsen, ex-artistic director of the Wynn Las Vegas salon. Nielsen made negative remarks about Wynn to the Wall Street Journal and ABC News. The reports included numerous allegations that Wynn forced staffers to perform sex acts on him. Wynn has denied the sexual misconduct reports, explaining that they're the result of a smear campaign by his ex-wife.
column65: Kilroy Realty Corp. (KRC) says it had funds from operations of $96.3 million in the first quarter. The results surpassed Wall Street expectations. The real estate investment trust posted revenue of $182.8 million. The company's shares have decreased 6 percent since the beginning of the year.. In the final minutes of trading, shares hit $70.06, a drop of nearly 5 percent in the last 12 months.
column66: Allianz says peer pressure on social media is part of the problem. Nearly 90 percent of millennial respondents say social media creates a tendency to compare their own wealth or lifestyle to that of their peers. About 60 percent of millennials report feeling "inadequate" about their own life because of something they saw onsocial media, Allianz study says. But, along with the " fear of missing out " on a new item, trend or experience, advertising does of course play its
column67: UBS is positive on Chinese financials this year, its head of China strategy explained Tuesday. "There's less worry about financial stability in China because a lot of other sectors are doing well," Gao Ting said. Steel prices have rallied in recent months due to tighter supply as Beijing restricts production in a bid to curb air pollution. On Monday, China issued stricter rules on building new steel production capacity to replace obsolete facilities.
column68: SpaceX was founded by Musk in 2002, with the goal of creating a new kind of privatized space industry. Musk personally invested $100 million of his own money into SpaceX. SpaceX secured several contracts totaling close to $200 million, including a deal with Washington. Even though the first demonstration of its rocket failed, Musk said the government was "reasonably happy" with the launch. He said he would be prepared to fund SpaceX all the way "until SpaceX was the top launch company
column69: Edwards Lifesciences Corp. (EW) on Tuesday reported first-quarter earnings of $206.6 million. The results beat Wall Street expectations. The medical device maker posted revenue of $894.8 million in the period. For the current quarter ending in July, the company expects its per-share earnings to range from $1.05 to $1,15.
column70: Cooper Standard has acquired 80.1 percent of LS Mtron's automotive parts business. Through the acquisition, Cooper Standard expands its core product offerings. Cooper Standard also gains a strategic partnership with LS Mountron, a leading Korean automotive and industrial manufacturer. This transaction further strengthens the Company's global market position in both businesses and strengthens Cooper Standard's strategic footprint in Korea, China and Brazil. About Cooper Standard: Cooper Standard is a leading global supplier of systems and components for the automotive industry.

Such quarterly dividends are only payable as and when declared by Rogers' Board and there is no entitlement to any dividend prior to that date. column72: Nordstrom is expected to report its fourth-quarter earnings after the bell on Thursday. The company is in the midst of its effort take the company private. Nordstrom is among a list of retailers, including Macy's , J.C. Penney and Kohl's , which reported strong sales this holiday season. It remains challenging to do so in today's retail environment, but the gloom appears to have eased somewhat.
column73: Coca-Cola shares moved higher by 0.7 percent in premarket trading Tuesday on the call, while Pepsi shed 0.8 percent. Goldman's 12-month price target for Coca-Cola of $46 a share is based on a 20 times forward price-earnings ratio. Monster Beverage is Hong's favorite pick in the beverage space because of its potential for international growth.
column74: Cathay General Bancorp (CATY) on Wednesday reported first-quarter net income of $63.8 million. The results fell short of Wall Street expectations. The holding company for Cathay Bank posted revenue of $165 million in the period.Cathay shares have fallen roughly 7 percent since the beginning of the year.. In the final minutes of trading on Wednesday, shares hit $39.30, a climb of slightly more than 8 percent.
column75: Disney CEO and Chairman Bob Iger said it will cost $4.99 to stream ESPN Plus. The over-the-top service will roll out sometime in the spring, in tandem with a redesign of Disney's ESPN app. The platform will feature about 10,000 sporting events each year, will have content from the MLB, NHL, MLS, collegiate sports and tennis' Grand Slam events.
column76: EBay and PayPal have also negotiated new terms through July 2023. This new deal does not extend the previous operating agreement, which would have expired in 2020. Though they were part of the same company for 13 years, eBay and PayPal were split into independent standalone businesses in 2015. After doubling in the past year and closing at a record $85.32 on Wednesday, PayPal shares sank 10 percent after hours to $76.58.
column77: Texas Instruments Incorporated (TI) will webcast its first-quarter 2018 earnings conference call on Tuesday, April 24, at 3:30 p.m. Central time. Rafael Lizardi, senior vice president and chief financial officer, and Dave Pahl will discuss TI's financial results and answer questions from the investor audience. An archived copy of the webcast will be available shortly after the call concludes.
column78: Motor Controls Inc. announced completion of the corporate headquarters relocation. The move enables full integration with our water treatment division (WET) and water distribution division (MCI FLOWTRONEX) This allows MCI to provide complete solutions, from advanced filtration and purification such as Reverse Osmosis, to Municipal and Commercial water distribution. Our advanced control and monitoring application to the entire solution allows remote support from MCI technical division as well as end user access and control.

The company serves more than five million metered customers primarily in Arkansas, Louisiana, Minnesota, Mississippi, Oklahoma, and Texas. With nearly 8,000 employees, CenterPoint Energy and its predecessor companies have been in business for more than 150 years.

The analyst reaffirmed his $265 price target onTesla shares, representing 9 percent downside to Monday's close. "I think there will be worries about fundamental profitability and/or worries about quality"

For more information about the Company and the Bank, please visit
column86: On Assignment Inc. (ASGN) on Wednesday reported fourth-quarter profit of $67.3 million. Earnings, adjusted for one-time gains and costs, came to 85 cents per share. The staffing company posted revenue of $679 million in the period. For the year, the company reportedprofit of $157.7 million, or $2.97 per share, on revenue of$2.63 billion.
column87: The Board of Directors of Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd. declared a quarterly dividend of $0.60 per common share. The dividend is payable on , to shareholders of record at the close of business on . Royal Caribbean owns and operates three global brands: Royal Caribbean International, Celebrity Cruises and Azamara Club Cruises. Together, these brands operate a combined total of 49 ships with an additional thirteen on order as of .
column88: The board of directors of Hillenbrand, Inc. has declared a regular quarterly cash dividend of $0.2075 per share on the company's common stock. The dividend is payable , to shareholders of record at the close of business on . The Process Equipment Group businesses design, develop, manufacture and service highly engineered industrial equipment around the world. Batesville is a recognized leader in the North American death care industry.
column89: Purpose Investments Inc. has amalgamated with its wholly-owned subsidiary, Redwood Asset Management Inc. There will be no changes to the daily operations of the business. Purpose has over $4.9 billion in assets under management and currently offers 50 exchange traded funds and mutual funds and 16 closed-end funds. Purpose believes in focusing first on managing risk and creating value that is currently missing from the marketplace.
column90: Elon Musk has taken charge of production of the company's flagship electric sedan, pushing aside former Apple executive Doug Field. Field will focus on "vehicle engineering," while Musk focuses on Model 3 production. Field had been consolidating power at Tesla, since leaving Apple to joing the electric automaker in 2013. Earlier on Monday, Jalopnik reported that Tesla was making 2,000 Model 3s per week.
column91: President Donald Trump declassified a hotly contested memo alleging anti-Trump bias and misconduct. The House Intelligence Committee released the memo just after noon ET on Friday. In a party-line vote on Monday, Republicans on the House intelligence panel overruled their Democratic colleagues and sent the memo to the president for approval. The memo was assembled by committee chairman Rep. Devin Nunes, R-Calif., who had worked on Trump's presidential transition team.
column92: Iridex expects full-year revenue in the range of $37 million to $41 million. The medical laser company posted revenue of $10.2 million in the period. For the year, the company reported that its loss widened to $12.9 million, or $1.11 per share. In the final minutes of trading on Thursday, shares hit $5.88, a fall of 59 percent.
column93: The KashMiner is a $3,400 bitcoin-mining machine. Kodak claims the machine will produce about $375 worth of new bitcoins every month. But others warn the $375 figure is exaggerated, as those bitcoin returns will diminish each month. The company's stock has more than tripled this week since it announced a pivot into blockchain technology and cryptocurrency. The move is a cornerstone of Kodak's crypto pivot.
column94: GSV Capital Corp. (GSVC) reported a loss of $2.5 million in its fourth quarter. For the year, the company reported net income of $17.6 million, or 80 cents per share. Shares have risen 68 percent since the beginning of the year. In the final minutes of trading on Tuesday, shares hit $9.18, a climb of 70 percent in the last 12 months.
column95: Chinese electric car start-up Nio says it welcomes competition from Tesla and others. China to allow full ownership of electric vehicles by end of 2018. Nio co-founder Lihong Qin: "If there is a green light, there should be a greenlight for everybody" He says the car industry has never been monopolistic, it should be open to all players, not just Tesla.
column96: "We just had too many momentum players," Wharton School finance professor Jeremy Siegel says. Higher interest rates will continue to be a challenge for the stock market this year, he adds. Even a 10 percent decline "isn't a disaster," he says. The S&P 500 added 32 percent from the November election through Thursday, so even a 10 per cent decline is not a disaster.
column97: IMI reported fourth-quarter net income of $116,000, after reporting a loss in the same period a year earlier. The materials research company semiconductor and clean-energy industries posted revenue of $10.5 million in the period. For the current quarter ending in April, Intermolecular expects its results to range from a loss of 2 cents to 1 cent per share.
column98: The Priceline Group will hold a conference call to discuss its fourth quarter 2017 financial results on Tuesday, February 27 at 4:30 p.m. ET. The event will be webcasted live at ir.pricelinegroup.com and the audio will be available for replay on the website for seven days thereafter. The Priceline group (NASDAQ: PCLN) is the world leader in online travel and related services.
column99: Philips says its fourth-quarter sales grew 5 percent to 5.3 billion euros ($6.55 billion) The company's intake of orders rose 7 percent, and sales growth was in line with expectations of analysts polled for Reuters. Order growth in the fourth quarter was strongest in North America and China, where hospitals stocked up on medical scanners and imaging tools used during surgery. The company said its adjusted earnings before interest, taxes and amortization (EBITA) rose 9 percent
column100: Broadcom said on Wednesday it had completed its move back to the United States from Singapore. President Donald Trump blocked its $117 billion offer to buy Qualcomm on national security grounds. Broadcom was a U.S. company until it was bought in 2016 by Singapore's Avago. The company said it exchanged all shares of Broadcom Ltd. to newly issued stock on a one-for-one basis and its stock would continue to trade under the same ticker.
